title: 105_s2355
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truancy Prevention and Juvenile Crime Reduction Act of 1998". Congress finds that truancy is a significant indicator of a young person's struggles, leading to school dropouts and increased likelihood of welfare dependence, unemployment, and criminal behavior. Truancy is a major factor in criminal behavior, with high rates linked to daytime burglary and vandalism. Up to 44 percent of violent juvenile crime occurs during school hours, and 75 percent of children aged 13-16 arrested for crimes are truants. Some cities report up to 70 percent of unexcused student absences, with total daily absences reaching 4,000. Truancy leads to criminal behavior, with high rates linked to daytime burglary and vandalism. Society faces social and economic costs due to truancy, with only 34% of inmates completing high school education. Truants and high school dropouts have a significant impact on the nation. Truancy prevention programs can reduce crime rates and improve school attendance. Lack of targeted funding hinders effective truancy prevention efforts. Parents may be unaware of their child's truancy, leading to long-term economic costs. SEC. 3. GRANTS. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "eligible partnership," "local educational agency," and "qualified unit of local government." The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines terms like "qualified unit of local government" as a local government unit meeting specific requirements. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 defines "unit of local government" as a general purpose political subdivision of a State or Indian tribe. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, grants funds to eligible partnerships to reduce truancy and juvenile crime. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 defines "unit of local government" as a general purpose political subdivision of a State or Indian tribe. The Attorney General grants funds on a competitive basis to eligible partnerships to reduce truancy and juvenile crime. Grants awarded under this section shall not exceed $100,000 in any fiscal year, with at least 25 percent allocated for use by the local educational agency participating in the partnership. Grants may be renewed for an additional period. The grant awarded under this section for a fiscal year may be renewed for up to 2 additional years. Grant amounts can be used by eligible partnerships to address truancy through parental involvement in prevention activities and sanctions like community service. To comprehensively address truancy, measures include parental involvement, sanctions like community service and license suspension, parental accountability with fines and community service, in-school prevention programs, and involvement of law enforcement. In-school truancy prevention programs may involve alternative education, in-school suspension, local community involvement, technology use, and eliminating incentives for truancy. The Attorney General may prioritize funding programs that replicate model truancy intervention projects in Fulton County, Georgia, and Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The Attorney General may prioritize funding programs that replicate model truancy intervention projects in Fulton County, Georgia, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Roswell, New Mexico, Rohnert Park, California, New Haven, Connecticut, Atlantic County, New Jersey, and THRIVE. The Stay in School Program of New Haven, Connecticut; The Atlantic County Project Helping Hand of Atlantic County, New Jersey; The THRIVE initiative of Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; The Norfolk project using computer software and data collection; The Community Service Early Intervention Program of Marion, Ohio; The Truancy Reduction Program of Bakersfield, California. The Attorney General may determine additional model programs for funding under this section. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001.
